Description: Five fragments of a narrow, dark brown hair and undyed cotton cord binding. Two cords have 1 element of cotton and 2 elements of hair 's'-twisted together. Two cords have a cotton string, consisting of 2 'z'-twisted yarns, and two elements of hair and the remaining fragment consists only of 2 'z'-spun elements of hair 's'-twisted together. Distinguishing features visible: an original appearing knot is present on one fragment of binding, and another has a small piece of woven textile adhered to it via mud or body fluids that, when they dried, acted 'as a kind of glue' (Nettie K Adams).
Dimensions: Length: 110 millimetres (3rd Fabric (small piece of binding found around main fabric))
Width: 9 millimetres (3rd Fabric (small piece found around main fabric))
Width: 11 millimetres (5th Fabric (at widest point: where extra textile fragment is adhered))
Bibliographic references: Adams et al 1999 / Kulubnarti III: The Cemeteries (p. 62)
Condition: Poor, dry/brittle and powdering material containing ingrained soiling.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Dr William Yewdale Adams
Donated by: W S Webb Museum of Anthropology (University of Kentucky)
Additional IDs: Excavation/small finds number: 93.2.11C (excavation object cat. no.)
